title: MARKET REPORT: DIY drought hammers shares in Grafton Group
text:
Grafton Group shares sank after it became the latest building materials supplier to warn that the construction slowdown and DIY drought is chipping away at its profits.

The FTSE 250-listed firm warned profits would be 4 per cent to 8 per cent lower for the full-year as sales suffered in its merchanting arm, which sells to builders.

Although chief executive Gavin Slark was quick to say that recent trading was more reflective of a nervous market than the nuts and bolts of the business, shares plunged 10.1 per cent, or 87.5p, to 781.5p.

Group revenue rose 0.9 per cent between July and September, but fell 1 per cent in the UK and 3 per cent in the Netherlands.

Grafton, whose stores include Selco, Buildbase and Woodie's, blamed a court ruling on nitrogen emissions in the Netherlands for holding up construction projects there, and, like many firms, pointed the finger at 'economic uncertainty' for the stumble in the UK.

The effect on Grafton's stock was contagious, sending peers down in early trading, though Travis Perkins recovered slightly later in the day to close up 0.1 per cent, or 2p, at 1457.5p. Howden Joinery was down 3.2 per cent, or 18.8p, to 560.6p, however.

The FTSE 250 climbed 0.2 per cent, or 33.15 points, to 20221.11, while the FTSE 100 closed 0.2 per cent, or 14.37 points, higher at 7182.32, after the UK and EU struck a Brexit deal.

Stock Watch - Feedback Medical technology group Feedback is in advanced talks with the NHS to trial its app Bleepa at pilot sites. The encrypted messaging app allows doctors to send each other pictures of X-Rays and other scans. Doctors usually use WhatsApp to do this when diagnosing patients, leaving them vulnerable to lawsuits. The firm is also pondering other commercial opportunities for Bleepa, within and outside the NHS. Shares jumped 4.2 per cent, or 0.05p, to 1.25p.

Domino's Pizza will close its loss-making international operations after it got a chilly reception from customers in Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Switzerland.

Chief executive David Wild said that while they represent 'attractive markets, we are not the best owners of these businesses'.

This will allow the takeaway chain (which is a franchise of the US fast-food giant) to focus on its British and Irish businesses.

The firm also added former Tim Horton's boss Elias Diaz Sese, who recently led the Kraft Heinz turnaround in northern Europe, to its board as a non-executive director. Shares rose 4.2 per cent, or 11.2p, to 277p.

Shopping centre-owner Capital & Regional shares barrelled ahead after it backed a £150million deal for South African firm Growthpoint Properties to become the firm's majority owner.

Capital & Regional, whose shares rocketed 25.2 per cent, or 5.35p, to 26.6p, recommended investors accept the offer, which would comprise a mix of buying shares from existing holders and releasing new ones.

National Express' stock touched an 11-year high after it revealed group revenue had accelerated by 14.5 per cent.

Shares in the transport provider, which on Wednesday announced a £869million Casablanca bus deal, closed up 1.2 per cent, or 5.6p, at 452.2p, but rose as high as 463p in early trading.

Price comparison site Moneysupermarket sank by 10.3 per cent, or 39.9p, to 347.1p after sales flagged in its money arm, which compares everything from current accounts to mortgages and travel money.

Revenue in that division, which provides 20 per cent of sales, fell by 5 per cent to £20.6million and the comparison site this would get worse.

It said there were fewer financial products available to compare as demand for new customers at banks and other providers has dried up.

Meanwhile, Rentokil's ongoing acquisition spree pumped up revenues by 9.8 per cent to £727million in the three months to September 30 and sent shares 2.4 per cent, or 10.8p, higher to 453p.

The pest-control group snapped up 15 smaller companies in the third quarter and has bought 32 so far this year.

Organic revenue, which doesn't include the new firms, rose 5.5 per cent.

It was particularly pleased with its fly control unit, Lumnia, which cut energy consumption by using LED lights to attract flying insects instead of traditional fluorescent tubes.
